title: 114_hr686
content: The Act titled "Small Business Mergers, Acquisitions, Sales, and Brokerage Simplification Act of 2015" provides a registration exemption for merger and acquisition brokers. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to provide a registration exemption for merger and acquisition brokers, except for certain excluded activities involving the handling of funds or securities in connection with the transfer of ownership of a privately held company. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to exempt merger and acquisition brokers from registration, except for specific activities related to handling funds or securities in the transfer of ownership of a privately held company. The exemption includes engaging in public offerings of registered securities on behalf of an issuer. The term 'control' in this paragraph refers to the power to direct management or policies of a company, whether through ownership of securities or other means. There is a presumption of control for individuals who hold certain positions or voting rights. The term 'control' refers to the power to direct management or policies of a company, whether through ownership of securities or other means. An eligible privately held company is one that does not have any class of securities registered and meets specific ownership criteria. In the fiscal year before engaging the M&A broker, the company must meet certain conditions related to securities registration and filing requirements with the Commission. The conditions for an M&A broker include earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization less than $25,000,000 and gross revenues less than $250,000,000. The M&A broker can facilitate securities transactions related to the transfer of ownership of an eligible privately held company, involving the purchase, sale, exchange, issuance, repurchase, or redemption of securities or assets, as long as they believe the buyer will control the company post-transaction. The M&A broker can facilitate securities transactions for the transfer of ownership of an eligible privately held company, ensuring the buyer will control the company post-transaction and have access to relevant financial information before finalizing the deal. The M&A broker can facilitate securities transactions for the transfer of ownership of an eligible privately held company, ensuring the buyer will control the company post-transaction and have access to relevant financial information before finalizing the deal, including year-end balance sheet, income statement, statement of changes in financial position, and statement of owner's equity of the issuer of the securities offered in exchange. If the financial statements of the issuer are audited, the related report of the independent auditor, a balance sheet dated not more than 120 days before the date of the offer, and information pertaining to the management, business, results of operations for the period covered by the financial statements, and material loss. On the date that is 5 years after the enactment of the Small Business Mergers, Acquisitions, Sales, and Brokerage Simplification Act of 2015, and every 5 years thereafter, each dollar amount in subparagraph (D)(ii)(II) shall be adjusted based on the Employment Cost Index For Wages and Salaries. The Bureau of Labor Statistics adjusts dollar amounts annually based on the Employment Cost Index For Wages and Salaries, rounding to the nearest multiple of $100,000. The Act and any amendments will take effect 90 days after enactment.
